feature_description: The map codes the expression of the superlative degree of comparison (‘X is the Y-est (of Z)’). We used the stimulus 'She is the most beautiful girl in the village.' (Russian 'Она самая красивая девушка в деревне'). For the map, only the first answer was taken into account. In all cases, the expression was periphrastic. The map shows the choice of the function word in the construction. Ibragimov (2004: 75) mentions modifiers bala ‘much’ and lap ‘very’ as ones which are used with adjectives to express the superlative degree. However, these words are originally intensifiers rather than superlative markers (cf. ‘very beautiful’ and ‘the most beautiful’). Our stimulus includes the designation of the set of entities involved in the comparison ('in the village'), and this allows to eliminate the intensifier interpretation (cf. ‘#She is a very beautiful girl in the village’) and to show the truly superlative functioning of the modifiers. Other, more apparently dedicated, options are the use of the Russian modifier samɨj ‘most’, the modifier derived from the demonstrative haasa ‘such’, the ordinal numeral saxusdɨ ‘first’ and the word sin ‘all’ used as the standard of comparison (i.e. ‘of all’).
stimuli: Она самая красивая девушка в деревне.
answer: had haasa bat'rad rɨs riʔi muɢʷaˁ
name: Назилле

feature_description: The map codes the expression of the superlative degree of comparison (‘X is the Y-est (of Z)’). We used the stimulus 'She is the most beautiful girl in the village.' answer: had samɨj bat'rad rɨš riʔi muɢʷaˁ

answer: had samɨj bɨt'rad rɨš riʔi muɢaˁr
name: Насим

feature_description: The map codes the expression of the superlative degree of comparison (‘X is the Y-est (of Z)’). We used the stimulus 'She is the most beautiful girl in the village.' (Russian 'Она самая красивая девушка в деревне'). For the map, only the first answer was taken into account. In all cases, the expression was periphrastic. The map shows the choice of the function word in the construction. Ibragimov (2004: 75) mentions modifiers bala ‘much’ and lap ‘very’ as ones which are used with adjectives to express the superlative degree. However, these words are originally intensifiers rather than superlative markers (cf. ‘very beautiful’ and ‘the most beautiful’). Our stimulus includes the designation of the set of entities involved in the comparison ('in the village'), and this allows to eliminate the intensifier interpretation (cf. ‘#She is a very beautiful girl in the village’) and to show the truly superlative functioning of the modifiers. Other, more apparently dedicated, options are the use of the Russian modifier samɨj ‘most’, the modifier derived from the demonstrative haasa ‘such’, the ordinal numeral saxusdɨ ‘first’ and the word sin ‘all’ used as the standard of comparison (i.e. ‘of all’).
stimuli: Она самая красивая девушка в деревне.
answer: had saxusdɨ bɨt'rad rɨš riʔi muˁɢʷa
name: Багуддин

name: Зейфуддин

feature_description: The map shows the means of expressing the meaning ‘at least’. The distinction is made between three non-cognate words, hadana (and its variants haadan / hadan / dan), bet (and its variant pet) and man. Please note that hadana and bet are verb modifiers and man is an enclitic, but mostly in our data these words are interchangeable, except for one response from Luchek where hadan and man were used together (ečbɨr hadan lewša-man). Also relatively frequently the Russian expression χotʲa bɨ ‘at least’ (and its variants χotʲ bɨ / χotʲa / χotʲ) was used. A special construction with the verbal form jišijne (literally ‘if become’) was attested in Khnov. Occasional periphrases meaning ‘somehow’, ‘a few’, ‘if you can’, ‘there is no choise’ were coded as OTHER.
name: Назилле

feature_description: The map shows the presence of the adverbial form of a noun (with ending -na) in the secondary predication of depictive meaning (‘X does Y [being] Z’). When the adverbial form was not attested, the temporal marker on noun (‘when being Z’) was used.

feature_description: The map shows whether the quotative marker xur (fu in Khnov) is used in reported speech construction. The first response for each of two stimuli is taken into account. YES means that the marker was used in response to both stimuli; NO means that the marker was not used in response to both stimuli; CONTRARY means that for one of stimuli the marker was used, and for another it was not. We used Russian stimuli that contained the Russian quotative marker мол.
stimuli: Он сказал: приходи, мол. Она говорит: не приходи, мол.
answer: hanow huxur: jɨq'a xur. hanow ruxʷara: maˁʁʷuj xur

feature_title: Imperative interjection “here you are, take it!”
feature_description: The map shows the form of the imperative interjection used when passing something to the addressee. Two stimuli were used, and they both showed the same result in each village.
stimuli: На, возьми деньги! На тебе хлеб!
answer: ma, leš šihibɨr! ma was xɨw!
comment: ma wes xɨw -- на вам хлеб!
name: Назилле

feature_title: Marking on adjective in adjectival predication “be X”
feature_description: The map shows the marking on the adjective in adjectival predication ‘X is ADJ’, including retaining of the attributive suffix (the value ATTR), a dedicated suffix (its form is given in the value) or absence of marking altogether (the value UNMARKED). Retaining of the attributive suffix is attested everywhere, thus the value ATTR is given only when no other strategy was observed.

feature_description: In some Rutul varieties, in constructions where the A is expressed by second person singular and P is expressed by first person singular, the two pronouns may coalesce and the ergative marker on the first element is dropped (also cf. feature «Coalescence in I-ERG you.sg-ABS construction»). The map shows presence of this phenomenon (as an alternative to the full construction).

feature_description: The map shows the presence of distinction between the inclusive and first person exclusive pronouns. The distinction is PRESENT in Khnov where two different pronouns are distinguished: inclusive jinewi vs. exclusive juɢuˁmbɨ. The distinction is OPTIONAL in Kufa, Rutul and partly in Kiche (in one of two responses). The distinction there implies that the first person exclusive pronoun je may be opposed to the juxtaposition of first person exclusive with second person singular pronouns — je wɨ ‘we you’ — which expresses the inclusive meaning. In our data this distinction is optional, i.e. je could be used in place of je wɨ. Please note that our data for Ikhrek is not sufficient. In one of two responses two different lexemes were used in opposing contexts: ži in inclusive and ji in exclusive. However, Ibragimov (2004: 180 – 181) mentions that these two lexemes have lost the semantic exclusive - inclusive distinction, which actually was the opposite to the one shown in our response: inclusive ji vs. exclusive ži. According to Ibragimov (ibid.), currently two lexemes are equivalent, though ži is used more frequently, which is exemplified by another our response from Ikhrek where ži is used in both contexts. As in Ikhrek we did not manage to check carefully whether the lexemes ji and ži are interchangeable, or they form a semantic opposition, we consider the data collected there insufficient.
stimuli: Ты нас не видел. Все мы люди
answer: was je ʁedgüradiš. je sin insanar diʔi
name: Назилле

feature_description: The map shows the presence of distinction between the inclusive and first person exclusive pronouns. The distinction is PRESENT in Khnov where two different pronouns are distinguished: inclusive jinewi vs. exclusive juɢuˁmbɨ. The distinction is OPTIONAL in Kufa, Rutul and partly in Kiche (in one of two responses). The distinction there implies that the first person exclusive pronoun je may be opposed to the juxtaposition of first person exclusive with second person singular pronouns — je wɨ ‘we you’ — which expresses the inclusive meaning. In our data this distinction is optional, i.e. je could be used in place of je wɨ. Please note that our data for Ikhrek is not sufficient. In one of two responses two different lexemes were used in opposing contexts: ži in inclusive and ji in exclusive. However, Ibragimov (2004: 180 – 181) mentions that these two lexemes have lost the semantic exclusive - inclusive distinction, which actually was the opposite to the one shown in our response: inclusive ji vs. exclusive ži. According to Ibragimov (ibid.), currently two lexemes are equivalent, though ži is used more frequently, which is exemplified by another our response from Ikhrek where ži is used in both contexts. As in Ikhrek we did not manage to check carefully whether the lexemes ji and ži are interchangeable, or they form a semantic opposition, we consider the data collected there insufficient.
stimuli: Ты нас не видел. Все мы люди
answer: was je ʁadgur diš. je sijena insanar diʔi
